issues.title: Efficient type mapping
issues.author: achamayou
issues.body:
- [x] Property labels to integers

There are 163 property labels in the 3.0.1 spec, and they seem to be the most frequently used values in documents, so it is natural to allocate them starting from 1. The current mapping uses the order of appearance in the json schema.

- [x] Const strings to integers

There are 337 string const values defined in the spec, they are allocated from 1001 onwards.

- [x] Enum strings to integers

There are 303 string enum values defined in the spec, they are allocated from 2001 onwards.

- [x] hashValue is a string in JSON LD, and typically hex-encoded although the spec is not precise (https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/v3.0.1/model/Core/Properties/hashValue/). A bstr would be more efficient in terms of space and processing, with Tag 108 to convey that it is expected to be represented as a lower-case hex string.

- [x] Datetime to CBOR datetime, Epoch-based/tag1: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8949.html#name-epoch-based-date-time

- [x] *Version are SemVer 2.0 strings. They stay as strings because CoSWID would only make them larger.

Regular expressions, need specific translation in cases where they remain (i.e. not DateTimes), see below.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
For binary values given in hex such as hashvalue, we could also use tags 23 (upper case hex) or 108 (lower case hex).

tag23: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8949#section-3.4.5.2
tag108: https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-bormann-cbor-notable-tags-13.html#section-2.1-2.2.1

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: That seems less efficient than the binary representation a bstr though?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: The tag takes a byte (23) or two (108).  Of course, the bstr in there can be un wrapped and the tag implied by the data definition.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body:
> Of course, the bstr in there can be un wrapped and the tag implied by the data definition

That seems like the best balance of precision and efficiency.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body:
```

samples/software/example3-src.json                              : JSON: 10915    CoSPDX: 6284      Ratio: 0.58 CoSPDXsr: 0.32 LZMA: 0.12
samples/software/example7-go-module.spdx.json                   : JSON: 2364     CoSPDX: 1325      Ratio: 0.56 CoSPDXsr: 0.43 LZMA: 0.38
samples/software/appbomination.spdx.json                        : JSON: 53063    CoSPDX: 35632     Ratio: 0.67 CoSPDXsr: 0.34 LZMA: 0.06
samples/software/sbom.spdx.json                                 : JSON: 14520    CoSPDX: 9285      Ratio: 0.64 CoSPDXsr: 0.33 LZMA: 0.10
samples/software/example6-bin.json                              : JSON: 16305    CoSPDX: 10829     Ratio: 0.66 CoSPDXsr: 0.46 LZMA: 0.18
samples/software/example6-lib.json                              : JSON: 12530    CoSPDX: 7451      Ratio: 0.59 CoSPDXsr: 0.32 LZMA: 0.11
samples/software/example1.json                                  : JSON: 11380    CoSPDX: 6588      Ratio: 0.58 CoSPDXsr: 0.31 LZMA: 0.12
samples/software/hello-src.spdx.json                            : JSON: 31165    CoSPDX: 20185     Ratio: 0.65 CoSPDXsr: 0.31 LZMA: 0.06
samples/software/example6-src.json                              : JSON: 8781     CoSPDX: 5208      Ratio: 0.59 CoSPDXsr: 0.32 LZMA: 0.13
samples/software/example4-bin.json                              : JSON: 16866    CoSPDX: 9976      Ratio: 0.59 CoSPDXsr: 0.32 LZMA: 0.09
samples/software/examplemaven-0.0.1-enriched.spdx.json          : JSON: 22245    CoSPDX: 13803     Ratio: 0.62 CoSPDXsr: 0.32 LZMA: 0.09
samples/software/examplemaven-0.0.1.spdx.json                   : JSON: 19651    CoSPDX: 11798     Ratio: 0.60 CoSPDXsr: 0.31 LZMA: 0.09
samples/software/example7-third-party-modules.spdx.json         : JSON: 3538     CoSPDX: 2021      Ratio: 0.57 CoSPDXsr: 0.37 LZMA: 0.31
samples/software/hello-dist.spdx.json                           : JSON: 7444     CoSPDX: 4851      Ratio: 0.65 CoSPDXsr: 0.34 LZMA: 0.13
samples/software/example5-bin.json                              : JSON: 8222     CoSPDX: 4852      Ratio: 0.59 CoSPDXsr: 0.34 LZMA: 0.14
samples/software/example3-bin.json                              : JSON: 11484    CoSPDX: 6640      Ratio: 0.58 CoSPDXsr: 0.32 LZMA: 0.12
samples/ai/simplehtr-example.json                               : JSON: 73134    CoSPDX: 49908     Ratio: 0.68 CoSPDXsr: 0.45 LZMA: 0.14
samples/ai/sbom.spdx.json                                       : JSON: 27271    CoSPDX: 11700     Ratio: 0.43 CoSPDXsr: 0.29 LZMA: 0.14
samples/ccf/manifest.spdx.json                                  : JSON: 4355500  CoSPDX: 1311058   Ratio: 0.30 CoSPDXsr: 0.16 LZMA: 0.10
```

Snapshot as of `af6a26b58cd06f62f52ef295416ab7ef13a0365d`, the ccf sample is good example of what can be achieved on the output of sbom-tool, with a step to make the Ids for compact (they are opaque to begin with): a rough total 70% decrease in size.

SPDX examples get less of a benefit here because their Ids are left intact, and they use large IRI strings such as `"https://swinslow.net/spdx-examples/example1/hello-v3-specv3/SPDXRef-gnrtd4"`. The CoSPSXSr results show that they land in a similar range once full string interning is applied.

It's reasonable to assume that a native emitter would produce efficient UUIDs to begin with, and so an early estimate for CoSPDX is "about a third of the JSON size".

issues.title: Sample converter script
issues.author: achamayou
issues.body: A sample converter script that can at least handle the examples defined under https://github.com/spdx/spdx-examples/tree/master/software is necessary for illustrative purposes.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: Basic converter: https://github.com/achamayou/draft-chamayou-cospdx/blob/main/conv/conv.py, to be improved in sync with schema changes highlighted in #2, #4, #6 and #7.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body:
These types of definitions pose a problem for canonical representation:

`prop_security_EpssVulnAssessmentRelationship_security_probability = int / float / tstr .regexp "^-?[0-9]+(\\.[0-9]*)?$"`

Discussed with @henkbirkholz the need to make a choice, and the consequent loss of round-trip ability between JSON and CBOR.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: So what is the definition on the JSON side?  Can I really use text strings with decimals in them?  (But not with exponents as in `1e-2`?). JSON does not have a separate integer type, so we could do all float for these values (which are presumably 0.0..1.0).

comments.author: achamayou

issues.title: Use cut operator at least in contexts where AnyObject is an alternative
issues.author: achamayou
issues.body: This it to make it clear AnyObject with labels that overlap with a named type but differently-typed values is not permitted.

comments.author: achamayou

issues.title: Add socket to SHACLClass and AnyClass to indicate possible future extension in later revisions of the spec
issues.author: achamayou
issues.body: Needs name-based special casing in gen.py

issues.title: Evaluate extending the context to intern strings
issues.author: achamayou
issues.body:
Experiments with string references as implemented by `cbor2` (https://github.com/achamayou/draft-chamayou-cospdx/issues/2#issuecomment-3655693265) show relatively substantial savings. SPDX has an explicit "context" mechanism that could be used to intern larger strings, and replace them with integer values without affecting canonicality.

This ad-hoc mechanism could be removed in later iterations of CoSPDX once https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-cbor-packed-14.html is finalised and available.

issues.title: Add validation of generated content to the CI
issues.author: achamayou
issues.body: The output of conv, currently used for size comparison, should be fed to cddlc for validation.

pulls.title: Add some analysis (and the output)
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body:
I put in some analysis code.
See conv/samples/ccf/manifest.spdx.analysis.txt

This code doesn't know about the enums used by conv.py.
What is the best way to find out if there is an enum for a string?
Maybe it is the simplest to run analysis.rb on a conv.py output.

comments.author: achamayou
cabo
comments.body:
So how do I handle label.*?
BTW, is it a problem that there is both a const.extension and a label.extension?

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body:
@cabo sorry, `label.*` is used for [keys in maps/attribute names in objects](https://github.com/achamayou/draft-chamayou-cospdx/blob/main/cospdx.cddl#L641) and `const.*` for [values](https://github.com/achamayou/draft-chamayou-cospdx/blob/main/cospdx.cddl#L966).

I'm not sure why it would be a problem that they are separate. Perhaps it's even an opportunity to use short integers twice, but I am not sure how I feel about `{1: 1}` where the first `1` means something completely different to the second `1`. Happy to discuss!
